title: 108_s2584
content: The "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" is cited as the short title. It introduces a credit for farmer investment in value-added agricultural property under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" introduces a credit for eligible persons or farmer-owned entities investing in value-added agricultural property. The credit is 50% of the property's basis, with a maximum limit of $30,000 for individuals and allocation among eligible persons in farmer-owned entities. The "Agricultural Producers Value-Added Investment Tax Credit Act of 2004" offers a credit for eligible individuals or farmer-owned entities investing in value-added agricultural property. The credit is 50% of the property's basis, capped at $30,000 for individuals and distributed among eligible persons in farmer-owned entities. The creditable investments for a farmer-owned entity are limited to the eligible person's investments in the entity when the property is placed in service. The credit for eligible individuals or farmer-owned entities investing in value-added agricultural property is limited to $30,000 per taxable year. Qualified investments made by the eligible person in the entity cannot exceed this limit. The credit for eligible individuals or farmer-owned entities investing in qualified value-added agricultural property is limited to $30,000 per taxable year. Qualified property includes items used to add value to goods derived from organic matter, with depreciation or amortization allowable. The tax credit applies to agricultural, wood, and animal wastes for properties with a useful life of 3 years or more, owned by eligible persons or farmer-owned entities. An eligible person is someone actively involved in farming. The tax credit applies to agricultural, wood, and animal wastes for properties with a useful life of 3 years or more, owned by eligible persons or farmer-owned entities. Material participation in farming business is determined similarly to section 2032A(e)(6), and an eligible farming business is not a passive activity under section 469(c). Farmer-owned entity refers to a corporation where eligible persons own 50%. A farmer-owned entity is defined as a corporation, partnership, or cooperative where eligible persons own at least 50% of the voting power and stock or profits interest. The definition of a farmer-owned entity includes a cooperative where eligible persons own 50% or more of the total voting power and patronage interests. Constructive ownership rules apply, with family members defined as spouse, children, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren residing in the same household or jointly operating farming businesses. The curr_chunk discusses qualified investments in a farmer-owned entity, specifically defining qualified equity interest as stock in a domestic corporation acquired within a certain timeframe. It also includes provisions for family members, such as children legally adopted or placed for adoption, who are treated as children by blood. The curr_chunk defines qualified equity interest as stock in a domestic corporation, a capital or profits interest in a domestic partnership, or a patronage interest in a cooperative acquired within a specific timeframe. The curr_chunk provides special rules for the tax credit section, including adjustments for married individuals, allocation rules for estates and trusts, and basis adjustments for eligible persons. The curr_chunk outlines rules for basis adjustment and recapture in the case of certain dispositions for the tax credit section related to qualified value-added agricultural property. The curr_chunk discusses rules for basis adjustment and recapture in the event of certain dispositions related to qualified value-added agricultural property for tax credit purposes. It includes provisions for when the property ceases to qualify, is disposed of, or the eligible person or entity no longer meets the criteria. Special rules apply in the event of the eligible person's death, with a 2-year suspension period. The curr_chunk discusses regulations for basis adjustment and recapture in relation to qualified value-added agricultural property for tax credit purposes. It includes provisions for the 2-year suspension period following the death of an eligible person and the termination of the section for property placed in service after December 31, 2010. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations to implement this section. The curr_chunk amends the Code to include the value-added agricultural property investment credit for eligible persons. It also allows the credit against minimum tax and specifies adjustments for basis and recapture related to qualified property. The curr_chunk introduces the value-added agricultural property credit under section 45G and amends the Code to allow for its inclusion in certain provisions. It also limits the carryback of this credit before the effective date. The Code is amended to include the value-added agricultural property investment credit under section 45G in certain provisions and limits the carryback of this credit before the effective date. The Code is amended to include a basis adjustment under section 1016 and a clerical amendment to the table of sections for subpart D of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1. The amendments made by this section apply to qualified investments made after December 31, 2004.
